speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: SCENE III. Another part of the field.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Alarums. Enter CASSIUS and TITINIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O, look, Titinius, look, the villains fly!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Myself have to mine own turn'd enemy:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This ensign here of mine was turning back;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I slew the coward, and did take it from him.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early;

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Who, having some advantage on Octavius,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Took it too eagerly: his soldiers fell to spoil,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Enter PINDARUS

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Fly further off, my lord, fly further off;

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This hill is far enough. Look, look, Titinius;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: They are, my lord.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Titinius, if thou lovest me,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And here again; that I may rest assured

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: I will be here again, even with a thought.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My sight was ever thick; regard Titinius,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And tell me what thou notest about the field.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: PINDARUS ascends the hill

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This day I breathed first: time is come round,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And where I did begin, there shall I end;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My life is run his compass. Sirrah, what news?

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: [Above]  O my lord!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What news?

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: [Above]  Titinius is enclosed round about

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: With horsemen, that make to him on the spur;

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Yet he spurs on. Now they are almost on him.

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Now, Titinius! Now some light. O, he lights too.

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: He's ta'en.

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Shout

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: And, hark! they shout for joy.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Come down, behold no more.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O, coward that I am, to live so long,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To see my best friend ta'en before my face!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: PINDARUS descends

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Come hither, sirrah:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In Parthia did I take thee prisoner;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And then I swore thee, saving of thy life,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That whatsoever I did bid thee do,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Thou shouldst attempt it. Come now, keep thine oath;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Now be a freeman: and with this good sword,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That ran through Caesar's bowels, search this bosom.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Stand not to answer: here, take thou the hilts;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And, when my face is cover'd, as 'tis now,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Guide thou the sword.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: PINDARUS stabs him

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Caesar, thou art revenged,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Even with the sword that kill'd thee.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Dies

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: So, I am free; yet would not so have been,

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Durst I have done my will. O Cassius,

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Far from this country Pindarus shall run,

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Where never Roman shall take note of him.

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Re-enter TITINIUS with MESSALA

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: It is but change, Titinius; for Octavius

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: As Cassius' legions are by Antony.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: These tidings will well comfort Cassius.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Where did you leave him?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: All disconsolate,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Is not that he t hat lies upon the ground?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: He lies not like the living. O my heart!

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Is not that he?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: No, this was he, Messala,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: But Cassius is no more. O setting sun,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: As in thy red rays thou dost sink to-night,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: So in his red blood Cassius' day is set;

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: The sun of Rome is set! Our day is gone;

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Clouds, dews, and dangers come; our deeds are done!

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Mistrust of good success hath done this deed.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: O hateful error, melancholy's child,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: The things that are not? O error, soon conceived,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Thou never comest unto a happy birth,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: But kill'st the mother that engender'd thee!

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: What, Pindarus! where art thou, Pindarus?

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: The noble Brutus, thrusting this report

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Into his ears; I may say, thrusting it;

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: For piercing steel and darts envenomed

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: As tidings of this sight.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Hie you, Messala,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: And I will seek for Pindarus the while.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Exit MESSALA

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Did I not meet thy friends? and did not they

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Put on my brows this wreath of victory,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: And bid me give it thee? Didst thou not hear their shouts?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Alas, thou hast misconstrued every thing!

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: But, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow;

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Will do his bidding. Brutus, come apace,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: And see how I regarded Caius Cassius.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: By your leave, gods:--this is a Roman's part

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Come, Cassius' sword, and find Titinius' heart.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Kills himself

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Alarum. Re-enter MESSALA, with BRUTUS, CATO, STRATO, VOLUMNIUS, and LUCILIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Titinius' face is upward.

speaker: CATO
text_entry: He is slain.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: In our own proper entrails.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Low alarums

speaker: CATO
text_entry: Brave Titinius!

speaker: CATO
text_entry: Look, whether he have not crown'd dead Cassius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Are yet two Romans living such as these?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The last of all the Romans, fare thee well!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It is impossible that ever Rome

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Should breed thy fellow. Friends, I owe more tears

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To this dead man than you shall see me pay.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come, therefore, and to Thasos send his body:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: His funerals shall not be in our camp,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lest it discomfort us. Lucilius, come;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And come, young Cato; let us to the field.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Labeo and Flavius, set our battles on:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Tis three o'clock; and, Romans, yet ere night

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We shall try fortune in a second fight.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt
